Molecular genetic analysis of plant disease resistance in diploid and hexaploid wheat

My research project is within the Wheat Pathogenesis Programme led by Dr. Kim Hammond-Kosack. It aims to dissect the molecular genetic basis of disease resistance in bread wheat (2n=6x=42, Triticum aestivum L.), and is is part of the core activities of the DEFRA-funded UK Wheat Genetic Improvement Network (WGIN), that involves scientists at Rothamsted Research and at the John Innes Centre. The project has four important goals: (1) to transfer defence signalling knowledge from model species (e.g. Arabidopsis, barley, and rice) to bread wheat
column2: (2) to use a diploid wheat Triticum monococcum to reveal the functions of key defence signalling components
column3: (3) to identify novel gene varaints in natural or EMS-mutagenised populations of hexaploid wheat by the TILLING technique
column4: (4) to provide commercially exploitable alleles in suitable UK germplasm to the wheat breeding comunity.

column1: The hexaploid wheat is not easily accessible for direct molecular genetic analysis owing to its large genome size (~17,000MB, over 140 times that of Arabidopsis), polyploidy, and lack of high resolution maps of molecular markers. To overcome these disadvantages, this project will employ the TILLING (Targeting Induced Local Lesions IN Genomes, Figure 1) technique as a novel candidate gene approach, which is also non-transgenic, to study the molecular basis of resistance in wheat-pathogen interactions. Novel variants of targeted genes will initially be identified and studied in a diploid wheat T. monococcum (2n=14) to avoid polyploidy complications. T. monococcum is chosen because it is closely related to the progenitor of the A genome of the hexaploid wheat (Figure 2) and is considered a rich source of novel genes. Furthermore, variant alleles in T. monococcum can be transferred into hexaploid wheat via conventional plant breeding.
A diagram depicting the TILLING technique
Triticum monococcum as a model to study wheat-pathogen interactions

Currently, the research is aimed at identifying variant alleles of known global regulators of plant defence responses in T. monococcum . Furthermore, a collection of T. monococcum wheat accessions has be screened for disease resistance and susceptibility to major UK wheat pathogens (Figure 3). Correlations between the disease resistance or susceptibility phenotypes of the accessions and the RAR1/SGT1 (Figure 4) sequence variants will be examined to establish specific phenotype : genotype relationships.

Figure 4.

RAR1 mediates R gene-dependent resistance via interaction with SGT1 and HSP90.

Other research focusing on identification of novel genes in T. monococcum involves generating appropriate F 2 populations that segregate at disease resistance and/or susceptibility. The genetic basis of resistance/susceptibility will be determined. SSR molecular markers to some of these resistance loci will be identified, and comparative genomic bioinformatics analyses undertaken to define a candidate pool of gene sequences residing within this chromosomal region for the subsequent exploration of gene function.
• Establish a high-throuhgput TILLING platform (in conjunction with Katie Tearall at Rothamsted Research, PS Department). This activity has recently been funded by the BBSRC (grant no. BB/C511056/1).
• Identify of orthologous RAR1, SGT1, and mlogenes in diploid and hexaploid wheat.
• Screen for novel variants of RAR1, SGT1, and mlo in diploid and hexaploid by TILLING.

• Identify resistance and susceptibility lines in a global collection of T. monococcum wheat accessions to the major UK wheat pathogens, including the Soil-borne cereal mosaic virus (SBCMV) transmitted by the vector Polymyxa graminis, the fungal pathogens Mycosphaerella graminocola (Septoria leaf blotch), Oculimacula yallundae / O. acuformis (cereal eyespot disease), and Fusarium culmorum and F. graminearum (ear blight), yellow rust, and take-all. These screens have involved collaboration with Kostya Kanyuka, Darren Lovell, Kerry Maguire, Martin Urban, and Richard Gutteridge at Rothamsted Research, and Lesley Boyd at JIC).
• Undertake genetic diversity assay of T. monococcum using SSR markers and analyse the colinearity between A m genome and the donor of the A genome of the hexaploid wheat (T. urartu).
• Generate F 2 segregatng populations and test to confirm variant allele-trait associations in T. monococcum.
